page.title: How do you DO Explicit Instruction?
page.contents:
Now that we've looked at the characteristics of Explicit Instruction (EI), let's look at how you would build lessons that contain EI characteristics.

EI lessons are built around these principles:

  1. Learning is focused on meaningful and critical content.
  2. What students are learning is precisely defined.
  3. Skills are sequenced logically.
  4. Students know what they will be learning and why.
  5. Teacher provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques: reviews, explanations, demonstration/modeling, examples/non-examples, and scaffolded practice.

During this course you will be asked to *apply* these principles as you create EI lessons for your own adult learners. To assist you in this process, let's look at each of these principles more closely.


Click on the Next button below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #1
page.contents:
EI Principle #1: Learning is focused on meaningful and critical content.

Given the planning and instructional time involved, we want to use explicit instruction to teach skills, concepts, and strategies that are foundational and will enable students to perform important current and future tasks.

Example: In teaching about the causes of the Civil War in the US, sectionalism can be considered a central concept. The Civil War was rooted in differences in the economics, social norms and politics of different sections of the country.  Learners can use this concept to examine how specific events reflect sectionalism in the Civil War, other current and historical conflicts, and even in their daily lives.

As the example implies, this means that not all skills, concepts or information should be delivered using an explicit instruction approach.

Non-example: In teaching about sectionalism, there are many details and specific examples from the Civil War that learners can connect with this central concept (examples: Who proposed the Missouri Compromise? What was “bleeding Kansas” and how did it reflect sectionalism?). Although this information is interesting and supports the concept, it is possible to understand the concept without mastery of this information.

Think of a unit or topic you teach. What is one critical learning outcome that is essential for students to master?

 

(Example and non-example from Lenz, Bulgren, Kissam & Taymans, 2004, p. 55-56)

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #2
page.contents:
EI Principle #2: What students are learning is precisely defined.

In an EI lesson, learning material is broken down into bite-sized chunks.

  • For skills and strategies, students learn a series of steps to follow.
  • For content learning, students work from a clearly delineated definition.

Click on the link below to explore some examples of breaking content into bite-sized chunks.

Examples of Breaking Down Skills, Strategies, and Content Learning

Now that you have reviewed these examples, take a moment to think about breaking learning content down into chunks.

Identify one foundational skill that you teach your students. List for yourself the steps they can follow to perform that skill. Do you typically teach your students these steps? Is breaking down learning content a new idea for you as an instructor?

Note that we will revisit the idea of teaching skills, strategies and content learning later in this course.

Click on Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #3
page.contents:
EI Principle #3: Skills/concepts are sequenced logically.

  • Teach easier skills/concepts before more complex ones.
  • Teach prerequisite knowledge/skills.

Example: Making Sense of Decoding and Spelling

The adult education curriculum Making Sense of Decoding and Spelling is an example of a carefully sequenced curriculum where skills build upon each other. This curriculum is for adult education students who are intermediate readers. Thus, the beginning of the curriculum ensures learners have the basic prerequisite skills to read longer words.

Explore Making Sense of Decoding and Spelling for an example of a logically sequenced curriculum.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #4
page.contents:
EI Principle #4: Students know what they will be learning and why.

The teacher introduces the goal(s) and rationale of the lesson. Students are thus partners in the lesson, and can anticipate what they are going to be doing as learners. Let's take a look at an example of a teacher introducing a Coding Text lesson.


Play the video below to watch a clip showing an EI introduction. As you watch, observe for answers to the following questions:

  • How does the teacher inform students of the lesson goal?
  • How does she connect with their prior knowledge?
  • Does she give them a reason to learn the strategy?

Video - Introduction: Coding Text

Introduction: Coding Text by NCFL

Video Transcript

If you are having trouble viewing the video, insert the link below in a new tab/window

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xtJvvSa-9Kw&t

This video excerpt used with permission from
The National Center for Family Literacy/National Center for Families Learning (NCFL)

Click the Next button below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #4 - Video Activity Possible Responses
page.contents:
While responses may vary, below we've listed below our answers to the observation questions for the Introduction to Coding Text Video.

  • How does the teacher inform students of the lesson goal?
    • The instructor simply states the goal for the students.
    • She names the strategy, "Coding Text."
  • How does she connect with their prior knowledge?
    • The instructor checks for understanding of the word “coding.” 
  • Does she give them a reason to learn the strategy?
    • Yes, she states that it will help with comprehension.

How did your answers compare with those above?  How does your current instructional approach to lesson introduction compare to what was demonstrated in the video?

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5-Overview
page.contents:
EI Principle #5: The instructor provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques:

  • Review
  • Explanation
  • Demonstration/modeling
  • Examples/nonexamples
  • Scaffolded Practice

Which of these techniques are familiar? Which would you like to learn more about? Which do you think you use in your current instruction?

Throughout the rest of the course, we will examine applications of these techniques as we explore EI lesson planning for skill, strategy, and content learning. So let's take a quick look at each before we wrap up our exploration of EI Principles.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Reviews
page.contents:
EI Principle #5: The instructor provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques:

Review

A review typically occurs during the introduction of a lesson to assist learners in connecting new learning to what they already know. During a review, a teacher can:

  • remind students of what they know,
  • refresh pre-requisite skills, and/or
  • provide interactive reviews.

Reviews can help teachers identify students who may struggle with the new content (or who are struggling with previous content).

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Explanation
page.contents:
EI Principle #5: The instructor provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques:

Explanation

Explanations present the new material to the learner in chunks and typically occur after the introduction of a lesson. During explanations, a teacher should:

  • tailor vocabulary, sentence structure, and analogies to connect with the students,
  • include a clear set of steps or concept definition that students will be learning, and
  • be as clear and concise as possible to minimize information overload.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Demonstration/Modeling
page.contents:
EI Principle #5: The instructor provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques:

Demonstration/Modeling

During the demonstration/modeling component of EI, students see what competent performance looks like. During demonstrations a teacher should:

  • show how to use the skill or concept and
  • think aloud to make thinking processes transparent.

The video activity you experienced earlier in this module is an example of the use of modeling to support learner understanding.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Examples and Non-examples
page.contents:
EI Principle #5: The instructor provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques:

Examples and Non-examples

Some explicit instruction lessons will include an activity asking students to discriminate between examples and nonexamples of the skill or concept being learned. This technique can:

  • help to quickly check for student misconceptions and
  • show a range of relevant situations in which students can apply their learning.

Let's take a closer look at the power of this technique.

Example: Below is an exercise from Making of Sense of Decoding and Spelling. Students discriminate CVC syllables (which have only one vowel and end in a consonant) from non-CVC syllables.*

Now please take a moment to look back at the sequence of lessons in this curriculum, and answer the questions listed below.

Table of Contents and Scope and Sequence for Making Sense of Decoding and Spelling

  • Is the ability for students to discriminate CVC syllables from non-CVC syllables a foundational skill for this curriculum?
  • Why is trans a good example syllable to include in this activity?
  • If a student is unsuccessful at this task, what can the teacher do? Why?

*Note that it doesn‘t matter how many consonants
come before or after the single vowel.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Examples and Non-examples Activity Possible Responses
page.contents:
While responses may vary, we've listed below one set of answers to the questions for regarding the CVC activity from Making of Sense of Decoding and Spelling.

  • Why is it important for students to discriminate CVC syllables from non-CVC syllables?
    This is a foundational skill of the curriculum. A learner who does not have this foundational skill cannot be successful in subsequent lessons.
  • Why is trans a good example to include?
    It follows the pattern of a CVC syllable – one vowel with one or more consonants before or after it. It shows the learner knows that a CVC syllable can have more than 3 letters.
  • If a student is unsuccessful at this task, what can the teacher do? Why?
    The student is missing an important pre-requisite skill for decoding and spelling multiple syllable words. The student needs more practice with this foundational skill of working with the short vowel sound syllables.

 

How did your answers compare with those above? Do you currently incorporate the examples and non-examples technique into your instruction for adults? When and how?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Scaffolding
page.contents:
EI Principle #5: The instructor provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques:

Scaffolding Practice

During scaffolded practice, the instructor gradually moves students towards independent performance and practice of the skill, strategy or content. During scaffolded practice, a teacher should:

  • Start with short and relatively simple exercises.
  • Build motivation and confidence when students experience initial success and feedback.
  • Prevent students from practicing mistakes.
  • Closely monitor student performance and provide feedback.
  • Increase task difficulty as student proficiency increases.

During scaffolded practice, instructors can structure practice as whole group, small group, partner, or individual based on students' needs.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Incorporating Techniques into a Lesson
page.contents:
We have just explored five techniques that organize and structure explicit instruction.

  1. Review
  2. Explanation
  3. Demonstration/modeling
  4. Examples and nonexamples
  5. Scaffolded practice

How might these techniques be used in an EI lesson? Let's take a look.

You may encounter many different Explicit Instruction lesson plan formats. The graphic below provides one example that clearly identifies three of the techniques we explored.

As you review the graphic, consider the following questions:
Which two techniques are not identified? Where could they go in the instructional process?

 


Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Principle #5 - Incorporating Techniques Activity Possible Answers
page.contents:
While responses may vary, we've listed below one set of answers to the questions for regarding the sample EI lesson below:

  • Which two techniques are not identified?
     - Explanation
     - Examples and nonexamples
  • Where could they go in the instructional process?
     - A teacher can use them when providing explanations prior to modeling.
     - Examples and nonexamples could be included as part of scaffolded practice.


How did your answers compare with those above?
How does this sample lesson format compare with your own?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Principles of EI - Review and Reflection
page.contents:
In this section, we have examined the question "How do you DO Explicit Instruction?" In answer, we have examined the 5 principles of EI and instructional techniques listed below:
  1. Learning is focused on meaningful and critical content.
  2. What students are learning is precisely defined.
  3. Skills are sequenced logically.
  4. Students know what they will be learning and why.
  5. Teacher provides organized and structured instruction using the following techniques:
     - Review
     - Explanation
     - Demonstration/modeling
     - Example/nonexample
     - Scaffolded practice

With these principle and techniques in mind, take a moment to think back over the course materials so far.

Can you find instances where these principles were applied to this course's instruction?
Have we provided you with precisely defined explanations? Demonstrations of skills or concepts? Examples and non-examples? Opportunities for practice?

 

We hope that you can - this is deliberate! And because we feel that EI is a foundational, critical instructional concept for adult education, you should continue to see these principles applied to your course materials and activities throughout the remainder of this course.

Course Reference: Linked below is a document summarizing the characteristics and principles of Explicit Instruction. You may wish to keep this handy as you complete course activities.

Characteristics and Principles of Explicit Instruction

Now we ask you to pause and reflect on what you have learned.
You will be asked to post your thoughts to a discussion forum.
 
 

Which one of the above principles (and/or instructional techniques) are you most interested in applying to your instructional practice? Why?
 
 
 
Click Next to end this lesson, return to the Main Course Menu, and access the Discussion Forum to post your reflection.
